



Network Working Group                          K. Nanayakkara Rathnayake
Internet-Draft                                   IETF Administration LLC
Intended status: Experimental                             29 August 2023
Expires: 1 March 2024


             Experiment with Unicode characters in xml2rfc
                  draft-rathnayake-xml2rfc-unicode-00

Abstract

   This draft is an experiment to explore what happens when various
   Unicode characters are on an Internet-Draft and how xml2rfc handles
   that.

Status of This Memo

   This Internet-Draft is submitted in full conformance with the
   provisions of BCP 78 and BCP 79.

   Internet-Drafts are working documents of the Internet Engineering
   Task Force (IETF).  Note that other groups may also distribute
   working documents as Internet-Drafts.  The list of current Internet-
   Drafts is at https://datatracker.ietf.org/drafts/current/.

   Internet-Drafts are draft documents valid for a maximum of six months
   and may be updated, replaced, or obsoleted by other documents at any
   time.  It is inappropriate to use Internet-Drafts as reference
   material or to cite them other than as "work in progress."

   This Internet-Draft will expire on 1 March 2024.

Copyright Notice

   Copyright (c) 2023 IETF Trust and the persons identified as the
   document authors.  All rights reserved.

   This document is subject to BCP 78 and the IETF Trust's Legal
   Provisions Relating to IETF Documents (https://trustee.ietf.org/
   license-info) in effect on the date of publication of this document.
   Please review these documents carefully, as they describe your rights
   and restrictions with respect to this document.

   3.  Scripts . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  10

   Author's Address  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 766

1.  Introduction

   Non-ASCII characters are allowed in RFCs under several restrictions.
   See [RFC7997].

   Some XML2RFC elements allow the use of bare Unicode and other
   elements can make use of >u< element.  See [RFC7991].

   Various non-Latin Unicode characters can be an issue in RFC
   publications.  Especially generating PDF format of the document.
   This is because the correct font has to be identified and included in
   the PDF file.  This is done by the xml2rfc too.  See [xml2rfc].

   xml2rfc maintains its own list of Unicode script blocks.  Depending
   on which script is used, xml2rfc matches the correct Noto font.

   This document is an experiment on when Unicode characters from
   different blocks are included in an Internet-Draft.

2.  Methodology

   The Unicode characters blocks are identified using [blocks].







Rathnayake                Expires 1 March 2024                  [Page 9]

Internet-Draft               xml2rfc-unicode                 August 2023


   The xml2rfc is used as an API to identify which script blocks are
   assigned to that character and predicted font names for set of
   characters from each Unicode code block.  The xml2rfc might predict a
   non-existing font.  These are the instances where xml2rfc might leak
   non-standard fonts to generated PDF files.

3.  Scripts

   This section covers Unicode scripts as defined in [charts].

3.1.  European Scripts

3.1.1.  Armenian

   Unicode character range: U+0530..U+058F

3.3.5.  Combining Half Marks

   Unicode character range: U+FE20..U+FE2F

   Unicode Combining Half Marks character list
   (https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/UFE20.pdf)

   Unicode character range: U+1BCA0..U+1BCAF

   Unicode Shorthand Format Controls character list
   (https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U1BCA0.pdf)








































Rathnayake                Expires 1 March 2024                [Page 592]

Internet-Draft               xml2rfc-unicode                 August 2023


   +==============================+=================+=================+
   | Character                    | xml2rfc scripts | xml2rfc fonts   |
   +==============================+=================+=================+
   | "ð›² " (SHORTHAND FORMAT LETTER | Common,         | Noto Serif,Noto |
   | OVERLAP, U+1BCA0)            | Duployan        | Sans Duployan   |
   +------------------------------+-----------------+-----------------+

4.11.  Surrogates

5.  Informative References

   [blocks]   Unicode, Inc., "Blocks-15.0.0", 28 January 2022,
              <https://www.unicode.org/Public/15.0.0/ucd/Blocks.txt>.

   [charts]   Unicode, Inc., "Unicode 15.0 Character Code Charts", 8
              March 2023, <https://www.unicode.org/charts/>.

   [RFC7991]  Hoffman, P., "The "xml2rfc" Version 3 Vocabulary",
              RFC 7991, DOI 10.17487/RFC7991, December 2016,
              <https://www.rfc-editor.org/info/rfc7991>.

   [RFC7997]  Flanagan, H., Ed., "The Use of Non-ASCII Characters in
              RFCs", RFC 7997, DOI 10.17487/RFC7997, December 2016,
              <https://www.rfc-editor.org/info/rfc7997>.

   [xml2rfc]  IETF, "xml2rfc", 8 March 2023,
              <https://github.com/ietf-tools/xml2rfc/>.
